Jack Settles
        
              
          https://lnkd.in/eQmzEEFj.

A great article from the Chief Information Officer at Goldman Sachs, Marco Argenti. LLMs are becoming more capable every month it seems, and one industry that people feel it will disrupt the most is software engineering. Given that LLMs can write syntactically perfect code, many feel that it will make learning to program obsolete soon. However, I think it'll be more like the calculator to math, or the printing press to writing: both were disruptive, yet innovative, tools for their respective fields, but ultimately they both helped increase the scale and complexity of calculations that could be performed and books that could be written, respectively.

"Today, we are at a point where computers (i.e., AI) do not need this intermediate level of translation between the language we speak and the one they understand. We can set aside the Rosetta Stone and just speak English to a computer. They will likely understand just as well as when speaking to them in Python. This immediately presents two choices: We can get lazy, or we can elevate our thought."

Thanks for the rec. Philip Walsh, PhD!

Md. Faiyaz Abdullah Sayeedi
        
              
          NVIDIA claims - AI ‘healthcare revolution’ already under way

Healthcare is probably the most impactful utility of generative AI that there will be. With generative AI, we’re going to be able to not only generate more ideas and predict with better accuracy, but we’re also going to be able to model biology in new and exciting ways so that when we put a new chemical entity into the clinic, we have a higher success rate. If you think about an ultrasound, or even robotic surgery and self-driving cars, they’re not that different. There’s lots of sensor data coming in, so there are real-time decisions being made. 

Generative AI will also be crucial in postoperative and follow-up medical treatment stages, such as when compiling a post-treatment report with patient data or reviewing a past surgery to assess its success.

Source: https://lnkd.in/g5vBu6a8

#AI #Healthcare #GenAI #Revolution

Vidhi Shukla
        
              
          🌟 Thrilled to Announce Our Latest Research! 🌟

I am excited to share our recently published paper, "Advancing Prenatal Diagnostics: A Novel Approach Using Machine Learning to Assess Fetal Well-being," in the February 2024 issue of TIJER. This groundbreaking research introduces a robust ML-driven framework for the early detection and prediction of fetal health issues, utilizing cardiotocographic data.

In this study, I took a leading role in developing the methodology and analyzing the data, employing sophisticated machine learning algorithms such as SVM, Random Forest, KNN, LVQ, and advanced ensemble models including XGBoost, AdaBoost, and LightGBM. These tools have significantly surpassed traditional monitoring techniques in predicting fetal health, offering deeper insights and potential for early intervention.

I am deeply grateful for the guidance and mentorship of Dr. Santosh Kumar Singh  and Rimsy Dua, whose profound insights and support have been instrumental in shaping this research. This achievement also wouldn't have been possible without the immense collaboration from my fellow researcher, Pranav K., whose expertise in machine learning greatly enriched our work and findings.

Read the full paper here to discover how we are pushing the boundaries of prenatal care through technology.
https://lnkd.in/dK7CvgVb

Joshua Anang
        
              
          MIT researchers found a way to reduce latency in Large Language Models by utilizing the L-Mul algorithm which performs integer addition rather than the hectic process of multiplying floating point numbers.

The numbers or values are instead converted into fixed point numbers or scaled by a 100.

E.g. two floating point numbers like 2.5 or 1.5 are scaled by 100 to become 250 and 150.

Integer addition is performed, and the numbers are scale downwards again by the square of the number they were scaled by which is 100. Hence (10000).

It is said to achieve precise results almost close to that of the traditional floating-point multiplication algorithms.

L-Mul with 4-bit mantissa achieves comparable precision as float8_e4m3 multiplications, and L-Mul with 3-bit mantissa outperforms float8_e5m2. 

This process is mostly required in scenarios were speed trumps precision.

#tech #LargeLanguageModels #Transformers #MachineLearning #DeepLearning

Tahaa Saeed
        
              
          🚀 AlphaFold3 is Here! Unlocking New Frontiers in Protein Structure Prediction 🧬
After six months of anticipation, Google DeepMind has officially released AlphaFold3’s software code, making it available for non-commercial use. This breakthrough comes as John Jumper, AlphaFold’s lead, and Demis Hassabis recently won a Nobel Prize for their pioneering work.
So, what’s new with AlphaFold3?
Unlike AlphaFold2, AlphaFold3 can model proteins in combination with other molecules. This powerful upgrade is set to transform drug discovery, as researchers can now simulate protein interactions with drug candidates—a feature previously limited by server access.
The Path to Openness
Despite initially withholding the code to balance accessibility with commercial interests, DeepMind’s decision to release the model paves the way for academic advancements. While some parameters, such as training weights, remain restricted to academic requests, this release is a huge win for scientific reproducibility and collaborative research.
But DeepMind’s Not Alone…
As DeepMind launches AlphaFold3, other companies have jumped on the protein-prediction scene. ByteDance, Baidu, and San Francisco’s Chai Discovery have each launched their own versions, with Ligo Biosciences offering a restriction-free model and OpenFold3 soon to follow.
Why It Matters
This open-access move is more than just a release; it’s about fostering a culture of scientific transparency. As Anthony Gitter from the University of Wisconsin-Madison puts it, "Open science requires that when claims are made, others can inspect the tools."
This is just the beginning. With AlphaFold3 now accessible, the scientific community is set to take protein structure predictions to a whole new level. 🌐💡
#AlphaFold3 #DeepMind #OpenScience #DrugDiscovery #AIinBiology #NobelPrize 

source: https://lnkd.in/dA9XDr74

Kathan Vyas
        
              
          As we strive to make AI models in healthcare more interpretable, we're uncovering fascinating challenges. Here's what I've learned while developing predictive models for critical care:

A) The Complexity Conundrum
Making "black box" models transparent often means adding layers of explanation. However, in healthcare, where we deal with intricate biological systems, these extra layers can paradoxically increase clinicians' cognitive load. It's like providing a detailed engine schematic when someone just needs to know if the car will start.

B) The Trust-Performance Tightrope
More accurate models often capture nuanced interactions between variables. While we can visualize these interactions, presenting them clearly without overwhelming healthcare providers remains a significant hurdle. A model that perfectly explains occlusion or thrombosis of a shunt isn't helpful if that explanation takes too long to process during a critical moment.
--Critical Insight: The goal isn't just to make models interpretable but to make their interpretability actionable and trustworthy for healthcare providers.

*** Key Developments
1) Regulatory Ripple Effect
 - Interpretable AI is creating new medicolegal and ethical frontiers
 - Questions of liability in AI recommendations
 - Added complexity in model development and deployment

2) The Bias-Awareness Benefit
 - Better identification and addressing of biases
 - Improved racial equity
 - Enhanced scientific reproducibility in healthcare AI

Question for Discussion
What are your thoughts on navigating the delicate balance between model transparency, complexity, and clinical utility in healthcare AI?

#HealthcareAI #Interpretability #ResponsibleAI #MachineLearning #MedicalEthics #Explainability

          🚀 AI Breakthroughs: Predicting Age & Sex from Retinal Images! 👁️✨

Sex Gap! 😬 

Recent studies have shown that AI can predict a person's age from fundus images with a Mean Absolute Error of ~3 years and determine sex with an AUC of 97% by analyzing the fovea, a tiny region in the eye.
These findings inspire several of my hypotheses:
🔹 Age Gap: The difference between AI-predicted retinal age and actual age might correlate with neurodegenerative diseases.
🔹 Gender Indicators: What anatomical features in the fovea reflect gender?
🔹 Genetic Links: Are specific genes influencing foveal structure related to gender?
🔹 Health Implications: Could discrepancies between AI-predicted and actual sex indicate sex-related diseases or ocular abnormalities?
💡 Exploring these ideas could uncover new insights into ocular biology and its connections to overall health.
🔗 Let’s connect if you’re interested in AI, ophthalmology, or genetic research!

Dominik Stosik, MD, PhD
        
              
          Teaching LLMs When to Retrieve Information for Improved QA 

Labruna et al. propose Adaptive Retrieval LLM (ADAPT-LLM), which teaches an LLM to dynamically decide whether to retrieve context via an IR system on a per-question basis. This approach is particularly relevant to the recently introduced Med-Gemini models, which leverage web search integration to improve clinical reasoning capabilities. The key steps in ADAPT-LLM are:

1. Prompt the LLM with just the question. If answered correctly, parametric memory suffices. If not, flag the question as requiring retrieval.

2. Construct a training set from an open-domain QA dataset. For correctly answered questions, provide only the Q&A. For others, add a <RET> token to indicate retrieval is needed, along with the Q&A and gold passage.

3. Fine-tune the LLM on this dataset to learn when to answer directly or retrieve via <RET>.

At inference, ADAPT-LLM either answers directly or outputs <RET>, triggering retrieval of a relevant passage that is appended to the question prompt for generating the final answer.

Experiments used Llama-2 (7B) fine-tuned on NQ and SQuAD, with Contriever for retrieval. On PopQA, ADAPT-LLM outperformed never/always retrieve baselines and matched a popularity-score approach. When ADAPT-LLM chose to retrieve, accuracy was significantly higher with context. When answering directly, it achieved high accuracy from parametric memory alone. Retrieval quality was a key bottleneck.

The adaptive retrieval approach in ADAPT-LLM aligns well with the uncertainty-guided search strategy employed by Med-Gemini-L 1.0 for complex clinical reasoning tasks. By selectively integrating web search results based on model uncertainty, Med-Gemini-L 1.0 achieved state-of-the-art performance on benchmarks like MedQA. The success of both ADAPT-LLM and Med-Gemini highlights the importance of judiciously leveraging external information to complement the parametric knowledge of large language models, enabling improved question-answering performance in both open-domain and specialized medical contexts.

Furthermore, one could envision an extension of this framework wherein the language model is trained to generate intermediate annotations or structured representations of the retrieved information that it deems most pertinent to the query at hand, akin to the note-taking process employed by human experts when researching a topic. This could potentially enhance the model's ability to distill and synthesize relevant knowledge from the retrieved context, leading to more accurate and informative final responses.

Abdulvahap Mutlu
        
              
          New Project!

I'm excited to share my latest project on EEG Eye State Classification! 🧠👁️

In this project, I utilized EEG signals to classify eye states (open or closed) using various machine learning models. The dataset, sourced from a continuous EEG measurement with the Emotiv EEG Neuroheadset, provided a fascinating challenge.

Project Highlights:

🔍 Dataset: EEG Eye State from UCI Machine Learning Repository 

🛠️ Technologies: Python, Pandas, Scikit-Learn, Matplotlib, Seaborn 

📈 Models Used:
Logistic Regression
Random Forest
Support Vector Machine (SVM)
Gradient Boosting

Key Results:
Logistic Regression: Accuracy - 61%
Random Forest: Accuracy - 93%
SVM: Accuracy - 87%
Gradient Boosting: Accuracy - 95%

I applied hyperparameter tuning to optimize each model, achieving the best performance with Gradient Boosting. 🎯

Check out the full project on GitHub for detailed code, visualizations, and results:
🔗 https://lnkd.in/drUkbKxF

I believe this project serves as a compelling demonstration of my proficiency in machine learning and my ability to apply these skills to EEG signal analysis. It exemplifies the integration of EEG signals with machine learning techniques, showcasing practical applications in this domain. Additionally, it was an enjoyable and intellectually stimulating endeavor.

Feel free to connect with me if you have any questions or insights to share!

#MachineLearning #DataScience #EEG #DeepLearning #Python #AI #ArtificialIntelligence #DataAnalysis #OpenSource

📂 Dataset: Explored and preprocessed a rich dataset of medical parameters.

Checked for missing values, duplicates, and inconsistencies.

Encoded categorical variables and scaled features for optimal ML performance.

Visualized relationships using box plots, histograms, scatter plots, and bar charts.


Machine Learning Magic:

⚙️ Leveraged Logistic Regression with:

Train-Test Split: To ensure robust model evaluation.

Cross-Validation: For consistent performance assessment.

Metrics: AUC, confusion matrices, precision, recall, and F1 scores.

Accuracy: Achieved promising results on both train and test datasets.

Insights: Identified key feature correlations with heart disease.

Marc Fiammante
        
              
          Just tested llama 3.1 nemotron 70b, here is the answer I got 🙂, I noticed that LLMs when they have been trained with complex puzzles respond with a complex answer to a simplied version.

Question: A shepherd is only with a goat and a canoe next to a river, how do they go on the other side?

Answer: A classic lateral thinking puzzle! Here's the solution:

The key insight: The puzzle states "a shepherd is only with a goat and a canoe" (emphasis mine). This implies there are no other entities or objects available except what's mentioned.

The solution:

    The shepherd gets into the canoe (alone, for now).
    The shepherd crosses the river (still alone in the canoe).
    The shepherd gets out of the canoe on the other side.
    Now, the shepherd is on the other side, and the canoe is empty.
    Here's the crucial part: Since the shepherd is already on the other side, and we need to get the goat across...
    The shepherd gets back into the canoe (alone again) and crosses the river once more to return to the original side.
    On the original side, the shepherd picks up the goat.
    The shepherd gets into the canoe with the goat.
    Together, the shepherd and the goat cross the river to the other side.

Everyone (shepherd and goat) and everything (canoe) is now on the other side!

          🚀 Exciting Project Update: Diabetis Prediction with Machine Learning 🚀

As part of my internship at Interpe, I’m diving into one of the most impactful applications of machine learning—diabetes prediction. 💡

Diabetes is a rapidly growing health concern worldwide, and early detection can significantly improve patient outcomes. Through this project, I am leveraging the power of machine learning models to predict the likelihood of diabetes based on various health indicators. This involves:

🔍 Data analysis: Understanding and preprocessing datasets
📊 Feature selection: Identifying key factors contributing to diabetes
🧠 Model building: Exploring algorithms like Decision Trees, SVM, and Random Forest
📈 Evaluation: Ensuring accuracy and reliability of predictions

The potential to make a real difference in healthcare with technology is what excites me the most! 💻💙

Stay tuned for more updates as I dive deeper into this project.

#MachineLearning #HealthcareAI #DiabeticPrediction #TechForGood #DataScience #InterpeInternship #AIInHealthcare

Aswin S
        
              
          🚀 Predicting Liver Cirrhosis Stages Using Machine Learning.

🎊I am excited to share my latest project on developing a machine learning model to predict the stages of liver cirrhosis! This project aims to assist healthcare providers in accurately diagnosing and staging liver cirrhosis, ultimately improving patient outcomes. Here’s a brief overview:🔍

Here’s a brief overview of what I did:

Develop a predictive model to classify liver cirrhosis into early, intermediate, and advanced stages using patient data.

Data Collection and Preprocessing:
Collected comprehensive patient records and handled missing values, Cleaned and normalized the data.

Data Preprocessing:Handling missing values.

Feature Engineering:Extracted and selected important features to improve model performance.

Model Selection: Evaluated multiple classification algorithms including Decision Trees, Random Forest, K- Nearest Neighbors,  Naive Bayes, and Support Vector Machines.

Model Evaluation: Compared the models using accuracy, precision, recall, and F1- score to determine the best performer.

The results were promising, with the Random Forest achieving the highest accuracy. 🌟

The developed model shows high accuracy in predicting the stages of liver cirrhosis, potentially enhancing early intervention strategies and improving patient care.

I am passionate about leveraging machine learning to solve real-world health problems, and this project is a testament to that commitment. Feel free to reach out if you have any questions or if you are interested in collaboration!📈

Check out the detailed notebook to see the full analysis and code:
https://lnkd.in/g93g-d6s
